title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Thing That Fixed My Winter Skin
body:
My face was basically a science experiment gone wrong last December. It was like 11 PM on a Tuesday, and I was staring at the bathroom mirror under that awful fluorescent light. You know the one. My cheeks were tight and flaky, but also somehow shiny in a gross way. My forehead felt like sandpaper. I’d just tried some expensive cream from Sephora—the La Mer one my sister swears by, which cost more than my electric bill—and it just sat there. Like a weird, greasy film. Didn’t soak in at all. I was so annoyed. And cold. The heat in my apartment makes this weird clicking noise when it kicks on, and it was doing that. Anyway.

I was desperate. I’d tried CeraVe. I’d tried that Kiehl’s Ultra Facial stuff. I’d even slathered on straight Vaseline like some people online said, which just made my pillowcase a disaster zone. Nothing worked. My skin just drank it up and asked for more, or it rejected it completely. Dry skin in winter is its own special kind of torture.

So I’m scrolling on my phone, half-watching some cooking show, and I see this thing about tallow balm. For your face. Beef fat. I actually laughed out loud. My dog looked at me. It sounded like something my great-grandmother would have used, or like a weird survivalist hack. But the person talking about it wasn’t a weirdo. She just seemed… normal. Tired. Like me. She said it was the only thing that worked. I was skeptical. Obviously. Putting beef tallow skincare on my face felt like a prank waiting to happen.

But the concept stuck in my head. Mimics human skin sebum. That made a weird kind of sense. Our own oils. Not some lab-made chemical pretending to be an oil. Just… oil. From a cow. Process of elimination, right? Everything else failed.

## How I Ended Up Putting Beef Fat on My Face

I didn’t buy it right away. I sat on it for like, two weeks. My knuckles started cracking from the dry air. That was the final straw. I found this little Etsy shop that made it. The listing was simple. No crazy claims. Just whipped tallow balm from grass-fed cows, made in France, with lavender oil in it. The lavender part sold me. Calming. Sleep stuff. My brain is always going a million miles an hour, especially at night. A night cream that might actually help me knock out? Okay.

It arrived in a plain jar. No fancy box. I opened it in my kitchen. Here’s where I have to describe it, and I’m bad at this.

It looked like… whipped butter. But denser. Kind of waxy? The color of vanilla ice cream. I poked it. It was firm but soft, like cold butter straight from the fridge. I scooped a tiny bit. Then I smelled it.

Not like a candle. Not like perfume. It smelled like lavender, but the real plant. Like if you crushed the flowers in your hand. Herbal. A little earthy underneath. Not sweet. It was strong, but not in a headache way. In a “oh, that’s a plant” way. It was actually nice. I was worried it would smell like a barn. It didn’t. At all.

Texture was weird. In a good way. Rubbed it between my fingers and it melted. Like instantly. Went from this firm balm to this silky oil. No graininess. No chunks. Just smooth. I put it on the back of my hand first. It felt rich. It soaked in pretty fast, didn’t leave my hand a greasy mess. My skin just looked… skin. Not shiny. Not dry. Just normal. Hydrated. Huh.

So I took a deep breath and put it on my face.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does

The first night, I used too much. I got excited. My face looked kinda shiny for a bit. I went to bed feeling like a glazed donut, mentally preparing to wash my sheets. But when I woke up? No grease stain on the pillow. My face felt… calm. Not tight. Not oily. Just soft. Not baby soft, that’s a cliche. Just like, my own skin soft. The flaky patches on my cheeks were smoother. Not gone, but less angry.

I kept using it. Just at night. After a week, the routine itself was the best part. The smell. It’s this timeless herbal smell, not fake. It signals my brain that it’s time to shut off. I put it on, and my anxiety about the next day just… fades a little. The act of rubbing it in is soothing. It’s become my thing. My 10 PM ritual.

The tallow itself is the star, though. This isn’t a moisturizer that sits on top. It goes in. My skin absorbs it. Completely. I read that it’s because the fat molecules in grass-fed beef tallow are really similar to the oils our skin makes. So our skin recognizes it. Uses it. It doesn’t just coat the problem; it seems to help my skin remember how to be a better barrier. For dry skin, it’s a game-changer. My rough hands from winter washing? Gone. I use it on my elbows. My chapped lips? Healed overnight.

It’s funny. I spent so much on fancy lotions in pretty bottles. This stuff comes in a mason jar, basically. And it works better than all of them. It’s the most effective natural skincare thing I’ve ever tried. I don’t know why it’s not in every store.

Oh, tangent. The smell reminds me of this little soap from a hotel I stayed at in Denver years ago. It was this boutique place, and the soap was in a brown wrapper. It had that same real, herbal lavender scent. I stole like three of them. This balm smells like that. Not like a corporate air freshener. Like a memory. Anyway.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of Tallow

So it’s been about a month now. Maybe six weeks. I’m on my second jar. I use it every single night.

The difference isn’t dramatic in a “wow you look 20 again” way. It’s subtle. It’s better. My skin is just… healthier. It doesn’t freak out when I go outside. The dryness is gone. Completely. The texture is even. It doesn’t get that weird winter redness anymore. It just looks like skin. Happy skin. I don’t need to pile on serum and moisturizer and oil. I just wash my face and use this. One thing.

I told my mom about it. She has this eczema on her hands that drives her nuts. I got her a jar for her birthday. She called me last week, confused and happy. “What is this witchcraft?” she said. “My hands don’t itch.” That’s the best review I could get.

It’s not magic. It’s just a really good, simple product. A tallow balm for dry, angry, winter skin that doesn’t know what it wants. It gives your skin what it’s actually missing. I sound like an infomercial, but I’m just sitting here in my sweatpants, being honest. It works.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. Obviously. I already did.

Look, if you’re curious about tallow skincare, this is a good one to start with. The lavender makes it feel special, not strange. It’s calming. It’s effective. It’s one jar that replaces like, five other products on my shelf. I don’t need a separate night cream, lip balm, hand cream, or cuticle oil. This does all of it.

It’s simple. It’s kind of old-world. And it just… works. I don’t have a better way to say it. My skin is quiet now. It’s not complaining all the time. For that alone, it’s worth every penny.

If your skin is being difficult, if winter is beating you up, it might be worth a shot. I got mine from that Etsy shop. Just search for whipped tallow balm lavender. It’s the one made in France. You’ll know it.

Anyway. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s the whole point, right?

---

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. It sounds gross but it makes sense. Our skin’s natural oil (sebum) and tallow have really similar fatty acid profiles. So your skin knows what to do with it. It absorbs deeply instead of sitting on top and clogging stuff up.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. And I’m prone to clogged pores. Because it’s so similar to our own oils, it absorbs cleanly. It doesn’t feel heavy or pore-clogging like some mineral oil or petroleum-based products can. It just sinks in.

**What does lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Like real lavender. Not a candle or perfume. It’s herbal, earthy, a little green. It’s strong when you open the jar but mellows out once it’s on your skin. It’s a calming, sleep-promoting kind of smell. Not sweet or fake at all.
random_tangent: that reminds me of that hotel soap from Denver, the nice one
